hobby.message: Still dodging towers with those drones?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: I suppose I am. Just keeping my head down lately.
Origami's what I do most nights. Makes the hours pass, at least.
Had to stop early yesterday. Some building access issues, system glitch they said.
Not much time for hobbies with all...this happening.
Still breathing, sure. Folding paper helps keep my mind steady these days.
Origami—little geometric shapes, modular cubes mostly. Neater than work.
Yesterday the power flickered, alarms blared. Made precision folds near impossible.
Everyone’s on edge. Even simple hobbies get disrupted now.
Hard to relax when the system’s this jumpy.
Yes, breathing. Barely. I fold origami models—complex ones, lots of little modules.
Helps keep me focused after shifts. Especially lately, with all the score weirdness.
It’s strange—last night, my elevator controls changed. Couldn’t fetch my scrap paper.
Without access, I had to improvise with old receipts. Not ideal.
You notice the smallest things—creases off, colors wrong—when your routine unravels.
Guess hobbies aren’t immune to chaos either.
Still breathing. Folding origami kept me grounded after that score mess yesterday.
I’ve been building composite structures—takes a lot of focus, keeps anxious thoughts in line.
Usually, I salvage memo stock from the office, but my card stalled last night—system flagged me.
Had to scrounge wrappers from home instead. The modules didn’t fit quite right.
You start to see how even minor disruptions echo everywhere—like trying to fold on a moving train.
Feels like the world’s patterns are coming apart.
Strange that something so small, like a score shift, can break your routine.
Still breathing, yes. Barely feeling steady, though. My origami hobby keeps me sane.
I do modular folds—dozens of interconnected shapes, geometric logic, oddly soothing.
Last night, after another audit at work, my BCI score dropped. I lost storage access for my scrap paper.
I had to use old bills and bus tickets to finish my model. Everything was frayed, didn’t fit well together.
Makes you realize how tightly little routines rely on the system running smooth.
Everyone’s desperate not to slip below the next threshold; it’s everywhere, even at home.
I notice neighbors peeking out, pretending things are fine—while I’m folding crumpled receipts at my kitchen table.
Feels like even my hobby’s keeping secrets for me now.
hobby_answer: Origami helps focus. Folding is... predictable, at least.
Last week, my table was crowded. Noisy in the building.
The system update hit in the middle of a model. Strange timing.
Hard to finish anything with alerts blaring all night.
Yeah, it does. Habit at this point.
I like modular designs—lots of small pieces fitting together.
Friday, the elevators got stuck mid-fold. System flagged us all, I guess.
My neighbors panicked, couldn’t get their groceries.
It messes with your flow. Hard to clear your thoughts lately.
It does help, actually. Folding sort of resets me.
I tackle these tricky modular things—kusudamas, sonobes.
Last Friday, tried to finish a cube, sirens everywhere, weird score drops.
Lost my folding space to emergency check-ins by neighbors.
My hands shake now, folding under all this system pressure.
Models don’t come out clean—they look warped, uneven.
Funny, the patterns are all off since the glitches started.
Yeah. I started folding years ago to handle stress at work.
Now I build complicated modular origami—makes the city fade out.
But that BCI mess last weekend... even my folding space was taken.
Neighbors were stuck outside their flats, calling for help.
I tried to help, but the elevator flagged me low-score too.
Ended up missing pieces for the model I started.
Hard to feel calm now—the system ruins routine things, even hobbies.
Feels like balance is gone from everything—not just the paper folds.
Definitely helps. I need my hands busy when my head spins.
Origami started as a stress trick during university, now it’s my go-to.
Used to fold complex spheres at the kitchen table after work.
When BCI glitched last week, the whole building froze—panic everywhere.
I brought tea to a neighbor who got locked out from a score drop.
Elevator wouldn’t let her downstairs, and my own BCI dipped, too.
Couldn’t access my supplies. Finished a model with scrap, it fell apart.
Even folding got tense—strange, how pressure warps the paper now.
It feels like the city is folding in on itself, all messy creases.
